comment: one of my favorite whiskeys these days.
I love the new American oak sugars on top of young malt, it makes for rich waxy baking spices
I get chocolate, vanilla and coffee on the nose.  Vanilla crème and almonds on the palate definitely a young malt.  The finish is medium in length and leaves you with sweet mocha.
Puchased at distillery in Seattle SoDo district
There's a lot of mediocre craft whiskey out there. These guys do things right and it shows.

Sweet on the nose, with hints of toffee, caramel, and vanilla. Some roasted coffee flavors at first taste, followed by a touch of almond and smoke with a nice, spicy finish that mellows out as you sip. Really tasty!
Definitely can taste the hints of coffee aftertaste. It worked well for me. Throw an ice cube in it to let the flavor come out.
Unreal how balanced this is for a 2-year. The defining American single malt standard of the middleground between scotch and bourbon.
Unbelievable complexity for such a young product. Almost a five star.

I purchased this thinking it was the Sherry Wood product. When reviewing  the DD site graph it seemed to align with MacCallan 12. Boy was I off. This American Single Malt is no bueno. I can't quite put my finger on it, and so I brought it into the office for others to try and tell me how bad my taste buds were, but they had similar looks on their faces. It's either a medicinal run or plastic flavor running all the way through. Weird.
Most brands can't put forth something like this for their standard offering. These guys know what they're doing. Love this.
I really enjoy the roasty, dark elements of this whiskey.

Interesting nose with some perfumey qualities, pine and oak as well.  Light but sharp taste, again with some pine coming through.  A little honey, some light fruitiness.  But mainly mild wood.  Not bad but not worth the $70 price tag in my opinion.  It is interesting and could be fun at a whisky tasting, just not something I'd buy again.

Nose: lemons, dill, raspberries, dark chocolate. Mouth: creamy, strong but not too boozy. I took a couple of drops and rubbed it between my fingers - got a strong aroma of pine. A customer told me it was "too scotchy" for him, but I find it to be an exemplary young American whiskey.
This distillery is awesome! Love visiting it every time I'm in SODO
Not an expert, but I know what I like.  Smooth and a joy to drink neat.
Almost a raw sugar nose. Slightly harsh but nice cherry flavor.
Coconut nose, bit of front burn, pepper, licorice. Finish with coffee and a bit of cherry cough syrup.

It was the surprise at our last whisky party! Coconutty smell, strong alcohol presence, lots of up front flavors and sensations. Peppery with some sweet malt flavors. A little antiseptic at the end maybe even a little cherry skoal.

On a recent business trip to India, I had taken a few days off to visit in-laws in Mumbai.  I had bought this for my brother-in-law , as something unique and not available outside the US (especially South Asia).   It's young, maybe 3-4 yrs  old, but hides its age extremely well.  At the onset, you can smell chocolate, coffee and cinnamon.   almost like Mexican cocoa.  The taste is a bit oaky, with a heaping dose of baked apples and cinnamon, followed by ginger and chocolate.  You get more coffee...espresso specifically.   It's definitely Oak driven, wood plays the integral role here.  Really well made, and in my humble opinion...better than most other new upstarts (with the notable exception of Kilchoman).  Also....on a side note---remy martin is buying this distillery.  So...two Americans now bought (High West and now this).
This is nice -- lots of coffee and vanilla in the flavor and very smooth. Nice and sweet finish -- Absolutely delicious.
Really very good, especially compared to how young it is.

Westland is a lauded single malt made in Washington state and is one of the leading lights of the American single malt movement.  I tend to be quite skeptical of these young, new whiskies, which often haven't had the luxury of aging long enough to develop rich flavors but then get graded on a curve by most reviewers.  That being said, this is very promising.  After a waft of furniture polish clears out and this dram opens up, apple, sherry, and malt produce a enticing, albeit uncomplicated, nose.  Its characteristic flavors are apple and malt, with a little bit of rising heat after a few seconds in the mouth, which is where its youth (two years in the barrel) betrays itself.  The finish is where this shines, starting with a brief, young oak note before transitioning to a deep, cherry chocolate cola note.  It's one of the best finishes I've had in a whiskey aged 10 years or less, better than many scotches.  I'm shocked this is aged in new charred oak barrels, with no sherry involvement.  I also love the 46% ABV and dark, rich, caramel color.  It's simple, but I'd recommend it, and can only imagine it's going to get better with age.  The Kilchoman of the Pacific Northwest.
It's so balanced that it's not memorable. While unobjectionable, nothing about it stands out.

Not quite Scotch, not quite bourbon, yet still possessing notes of each. On second tasting (first tasting ruined by caramel ice cream just prior to tasting) I definitely got a rich sweetness mixed with a woody, pine-tree-like taste. Chocolate, caramel, pepper and definite hints of tobacco and wood, this is not a top-shelf whiskey for me but still a decent treat.
bourbon meets Scotch with a stronger oaky bourbon flavor, bit of a bite, but great flavor
I get a ton of banana on the nose and chocolate and dark coffee on the palate, especially towards the finish. It's pretty different and I find it rather enjoyably sippable.

Nose - Hint of vanilla, dried apples, dark chocolate laden sweet bread, oaked chardonnnay, hint of orange zest.
Taste - Sweet honey, toasted oat cereal, like Honey Smacks cereal, caramel corn, Cracker Jack, cocoa nibs, creme brulee, dried apples.
Finish - Lingering Cracker Jack / caramel corn, cocoa nibs, latte foam, sweet roasted nuts.
Score - 88/100
Final Thoughts - I like what Westland is doing with their multi-malt mashbill. I think their pale chocolate malt and brown malt add this very nice nuttiness that helps hide this whiskey's youth very well. Their standard offering is very tasty on its own given its youth and I can only imagine what some additional time in barrels will do to mellow out this malt and smooth out the rough edges.

I'm giving this one three stars, but I think I'm being generous. For every aroma I found pleasant, I was met with another note that harmed the experience. Close your eyes and imagine maltiness, maple syrup, clove and vanilla trying to play nice with glue and rotten wood... Not very pleasant.

Unidentifiable funk, sweetness on the nose.  Funk not unpleasant.  Tastes like caramel, vanilla, and popcorn!?  Finishes with smooth oak and sweetness that lingers for a bit.  Quite a unique single malt!

First of its category. Tasted after touring the distillery in Seattle in August 2016 with Laura. After smelling and handling the barley used, tasting the wash from the tank and nosing the raw spirit before barreling, this was easy to fall in love with! One of my favorites. The "single barrel" mini bottle (at barrel strength, straight from the barrel) was bottled by Laura and I, and only to be opened on a special occasion of her choosing in the future!
Erg lekkere zachte zoete whisky die aardig lang blijft hangen

[LOOK] Mead [NOSE] Turkish delight, malty, Belgian ale, sunflower seeds, vanilla, ginger snaps [PALATE] Yeast doughnut, candied egg yolks, heavy cream, almond biscotti, biscuitty [FINISH] Medium length, full, sweet malt blends to espresso, chocolate malts [MOUTHFEEL] Thin, light, pleasant, warm
3.5. Strong sweet fruit, kinda like melon but not. I can’t figure out what   Bit of a burn and same aftertaste.
Nose: cherry, caramel; Palate: Humid wood, coffee, black liquorice; Finish: coffee, black liquorice. A distinctive whisky and a stunning NAS, but at $107 at SAQ in Quebec, it’s an expensive bourbon.
I get the vanilla, maybe a little bit of licorice, unfortunately. has a smokiness to it but different than scotch
Excellent front. Mild middle. scotch made in america.
Interest flavors of cinnamon vanilla and chocolate it must get from those American oak barrels. Reminds me a bit much of fireball in a sickly way though
Subtle chocolate flavor.  Spicy on the tongue and not in the throat.

Dried fruits, licorice, and floral spices come through a remarkably oily and thick dram. The nose is the sweet scent of a mountain blackberry patch; green, ripe, overripe, and fresh.  The finish is long, sweet, and full of savory cherries.

damn. Chocolate whiskey. Reminds me of camping? Citrus on the nose, oak chocolate on the tongue. If I went camping in the woods, bring this! This would be lovely to have by a campfire, no smoke on it either.
3 of the 5 malts toasted; the chocolate malt has a lingering cocoa in the finish. Smoky notes, as well
Share with friends, just a good whiskey. This is the only none scotch in my cabinet but when friends are around this is the first to come out.

It’s young, but has enough complexity and interest to keep me coming back.  Nice sweet nose and richness on the front.  Finish isn’t completely absent but is a bit light and leaves me wanting more. The back half bitterness is a nice touch. Really curious to see where this goes with age.  Looking forward to the 8 year!
It’s better than a 1 star, but it is way too steep of a price for the quality
Different, sherries like scotch, double barreled, single malt (barely), intense like scotch. 8th try gosling.

very distinctive memories of stouts and porters I drank 15 years ago in the Pacific Northwest hit me hard on the finish of the first taste.
nose has dark chocolate covered bananas, toffee, ripe fruit.
medium roast coffee notes at the back: bitter, dry then hardwood lumber. 

really enjoyed this!
Tastes much better than its rating, and stronger...
Tried this at whiskey washback. Very good stuff with notes of caramel, bananas, chocolate, and malty cereal.
Smooth at the beginning with a sudden strong finish.
Honey on the nose with a woody, sort of, idk, I’m in the middle of the forest finish

Note: Tasty and holds tremendous promise for an American Single Malt but rather expensive and just tastes young and a bit too sweet.
Smell: Toasted cereal, vanilla, citrus( or apple?)
Taste: Sweet, syrupy, creamy, warm, cherry.
Finish: Hint of dark caramel/coffee, mild oaky dryness, cinnamon, mid finish.

With the holiday season (mostly) a wrap, a wee dram to fortify oneself against the winter chill is in order while I get in the seed order for this year's garden. My wife told me to "go buy some whiskey that you'll like" as part of my Christmas present, so...I took her up on that. Granted, buying a bottle of something I've haven't tasted before is a bit of a gamble, but this one paid off nicely, and I've no reason to doubt the judgment of the golden palated folks here who've sung the praises of Westland.

The biggest note for me here is chocolate, and in a few different forms...at various moments in time, I get baking chocolate, spiced Mexican dark chocolate, hot cocoa, and fudge. While the chocolate notes are the most obvious, there are some notes of espresso, dried fig, vanilla, and coconut. I even get the faintest hint of charred wood in the background, almost like someone in the neighborhood's just gotten a charcoal grill started. The mouthfeel is deliciously coating, but not heavy.

My sole complaint is that there's a definite youthfulness here...it's a younger distillery, so this isn't a huge shocker, but I did need to let the dram sit for a bit to open up since there was a definite ethanol heat on initial pouring. I'd have loved this bottle at, say, $10 less, but I still feel like I got what I paid for at about $60. Still, if this is what their entry level whiskey is like, I can't wait to get my hands on some of their other output.
Brown sugar, baking spices, banana bread, pipe tobacco, toast, caramel green apple and a floral note. Orange creme, coffee, and a bit of chocolate. Nice long finish.

nose reminds me a very toned down balcones, which is a good thing.
taste of coffee! oh I like this
Cherry, chocolate, and a bit of coffee. Good pour. I'm new to American single malts, but I'm definitely happy with this one.
Not bad. Expensive though. Hints of coffee, vanilla, spices. Cheaper single malts out there that are just as good or better.
6 year private bottling. 53.  Up front. Decent

I can drink this all day! Bring me back to the beach and the off shore breeze and the mist from the ocean 🌊 and the bomb fires after a long day shredding the waves! 

So god damn good dram!

At the picturesque Biltmore Estate sitting by a fireplace, not a much better setting for a nice dram. Westland is part of my list of American Single Malts and I have heard nothing but good things. 
The one thing I am learning about American single malts is just how different and unique they all are. There really is no overriding common flavor profile. 
This one is amongst the most unique. The overriding note is peanut brittle and nut butter. It's really dominant. The body is pretty viscous and with a medium peanut and oak driven finish. 
Unique. Worth a pour, sure. Worth a bottle? Not for me.
Always solid. Woody, oakey toasty notes. Always a winner.
Apples and citrus on the nose.  Palette is sweet at first then earthy with a boosh at the end that turns into a leathery finish.
Smoky, rich, full bodied. Very smooth.

On the nose I found quite a lot of fruit sweetness and the barley used makes its uniqueness known I can just grasp a hint of coffee mixed with vanilla and some caramel. On the palate I found more of the same fruits. Strawberries and cherries mixed in with oranges, lemons, and even kiwis as well as that vanilla however it's subtle enough to not over power the fruit but truly compliments it. Its well rounded and very flavorful. On the finish I am once again exposed to that coffee note so many find and love Westland for. It makes the finish worth savoring.  This has made me want to fall in love with Westland and has earned it a permanent spot in my permanent collection.

I walked into my local Total Wine looking for some bourbon when, lo and behold, I see the Westland Single Malt on CLEARANCE for $49. I didn’t even know Total Wine had clearance whiskey! I should’ve grabbed more than one bottle.

The nose is nothing too radical. Some spice with vanilla, maple from the new char oak barrel. The taste was the most interesting part. This has a subtle coffee cream flavor that coats the mouth. It’s silky, and the taste stays with you for some time. The finish changes from coffee to a nutty flavor that I really enjoyed. 

Honestly this has become one of my favorite American single malts. It sits proudly next to my bottle of Balcones “1” Texas single malt which I love. Is it worth the retail price of $70? Meh... but it was definitely worth the $49 I paid today!

Nose: spice, herbs, sweet, strong vanilla
Palate: strong spice and vanilla, hot, oily
Finish: Lingers
Honey and jammy fruit on the nose, same on palate with a little late-to-mid-palate wood spice, and a medium finish. Pleasant but not much in the way of complexity.
Approachable and flavorful.  Coffee chocolate. Soft. From whisky kitchen.

Definitely tastes young and spicy but there is a lot of good flavor. Nose is kinda meh. Coffee and cinnamon and spice on the palate. Finish is nothing special. Would like to taste this same thing after a few more years aging.

The best Washington whiskey I’ve had. Solid nose that is reaffirmed by the taste. Moderate burn that really plays off the single malt, perfect after dinner drink for a rye lover. Lovely when drunk neat.

Nose - vanilla, graham cracker and clove 

Taste - cherry, vanilla, clove and some chocolate 

Finish - warm spice and a little sweet 

A little more flavor and smokier than Glenlivet
Balanced and smooth. Nothing overpowering on the nose and no dominating favors on the tongue.  Some vanilla, and hints of fruit on the nose.  Woodsy but mild taste.

Sweet and Woody aromas, smells complex from the start. Mostly wood and grain flavor on the tongue, the new wood barrels gives it tons of flavor. The malt also sits forever on the tail. Very strong flavors in a rich body. Malted barley have hints of sweetness too, maybe from fruit flavors.
Tastes like Cherry Coke except not quite as sweet. Haven't had anything like this before!

With one splinter of ice American Oak doesn’t quite crack open; but rather, is tamed. Neat vs rocks is like breaking a horse or taming the frontier. Wow. This was a special taste... if you prefer neat and thought Westland was just so-so, take a walk on the mild side with a chunk o’ H2O and I promise you’ll get it.

Nothing says “PNW” like Westland. It feels like the weather and habitants of Seattle: dramatic, independent, steadfast. 
American oak somehow feels more distinct than the peat and sherry offerings with a profile all its own. I’m noticing the tannins more, and a little water popped out a raisin note that I hadn’t previously noticed.

Westland American
Age: 3 years
Proof: 92
Natural Color
Non- chill filtered
Nose:  straight oak tannins. Slight hints of caramel & vanilla 
Palate: Rich. Peppery. Vanilla and caramel
Mouthfeel: moderate
Finish:  bright, more pepper with lots of vanilla chasing the pepper. 

Score: A- 
I can see this being worth the $70 price.
Very aromatic. Strong young flavor and heat. Burnt nut taste. So so

Sweet, roasted malt. Coffee or dark chocolate mixed with dried or leather fruits. Some dark citrus too. Flavour is complex. More brown sugar, caramel, vanilla. Coffee or roasted grains builds. It is peppery from youth in the palate. The fruit fades and grain, roast notes take over. The finish is drying, grassy, and lingering. After a time I'm left with espresso notes and a pleasant bitter notes on the edges of my mouth. This is good

Nose - I'm getting grape bubble gum, oak, christmas spices, and vanilla.  

Taste - Sweet malt...I can't place this malt note.  Wood funk, cloves and other spices, some grass, and fall fruits.  On the finish I get some vanilla and more oak.  

A very unique whisky that has really opened up in the bottle.  Gosh just so unique.  I want to say this was about 50 bucks and it's a good buy at that price.  

I'm leaving it at a 2.75, it's very good but it's so strange that some will really not care for it.  A must get for the adventurous but all others try it first.

I read an article recently about how distilleries were seeking inspiration from breweries in the malts and yeast types and how American was leading the way.  I thought I'd really like to try something like that (done better than the 2nd Edition Glenmorangie Signet I had) and then promptly forgot about it. Next day having randomly selected a dram I tasted it and thought eh this is interesting, read the bio and low and behold a mixture of different malts and  belgian yeast. You really do get the cocoa, chocolate coming through from the dark malts and that's after drinking a cocoa milk stout beer (and Bunnahabhain 18 in between). Would have loved to pair the beer with this whiskey. It's a young whiskey with a slightly thin body and aftertaste but that's to be expected.. you don't want the cask to overpower the spirit. I'd love to see what a decade more would do.
Coconut, clove and vanilla. Sweet nose, and very light and easy to sip.
Light sweetness in the beginning, finishes very oaky and sharp. Very very little alcohol burn, very friendly and easy to drink. Tasted in a glencairn
Rich and smooth chocolaty smell. Strong finish. Tastes of Swiss chocolate and coffee.

Nose of crisp apples, a bit of Carmel. Tastes very smooth. I do pick up the tobacco and leather, but it's a bit too subtle for me. Reminds me of a lot of Irish whiskeys, like Redbreast, which isn't a good thing. Makes me think I'm drinking a vodka not a whiskey.
Malted milk on the finish. Creamy.

I’m getting maraschino cherries up front on the nose. Also a red apple, like a gala or fuji. Taste I’m getting a little bit of brown sugar and maple. A small amount of dark coffee. Wood. An all time favorite of mine. I discover more the more I drink it. Tasted in Glencairn.

Nose: Chocolate Covered Coffee Beans, Vanilla, Malt, Leather

Taste: Chocolate Covered Coffee Beans, Vanilla, Leather, Malt
Not hot. Oakey flavor. The lingering flavor is nice and and the whiskey to me becomes smoother. One for my bar.

The immediate nose is banana! And caramel? Bananas foster! Wild! Obviously above 40% from the nose, but nothing crazy. The flavour of bananas carries through the palate with some chocolate and coffee flavours. The finish is a bit hot and long lasting, lovely lingering sweetness. I didn’t know an American single malt could be this great!
Vanilla coffee toffee nose. Kind of drunk so I can’t pick anything on taste but a slightly Smokey finish.

Perusing the ABC Store aisles in a larger neighboring county, I came across this one on sale for $38. I wondered why I had never given this $40'ish dollar single malt a try (NC sale items are usually only a couple dollars off), so I picked one up. It was only after I got home, sampled and liked it, that I decided to look up the regular price. That's when I realized why I had never given this one a second glance. It's regular price is $70! NC must be closing this one out...Now on to my tasting notes.
NOSE: Unique. Leather, Unlit Cigar, Oak, Toffee, Tea, Hay, maybe a hint of Orange Peel, all wrapped in a light floral note.
NEAT: Enters slightly Bitter and Hoppy, like a Stout Beer. Chocolate Covered Espresso Beans, Burnt Popcorn, Unsweetened Dark Chocolate, and Unlit Cigar. Finishes with a medium length light tingle. The palate is coated with a touch of sweetness that lingers on the palate along with a smoky/ashy almost peaty flavor.
SPLASH: Ups the Floral Note on the nose while adding tea to the palate. Also amplifies the lingering Ashy Note. 
VERDICT: Different and Delicious. Before I became a seasoned whiskey drinker I knew what Bourbon and Jack and Crown tasted like just from casual drinking. This is what I imagined scotch tasting like. I'm not sure that I'd consider this a great $70 whiskey, but I damn sure consider it a great $40 whiskey. So much so that I went back and blew my next two months liquor budget on 5 more bottles. If you are in NC, seek this one out at the close out price of $38, and thank me later.

Not a scotch/single malt fan, but I have to say I was impressed by this. Nose and Palate of roasted coffee beans covered in dark chocolate. The roasted note stays with you on the finish, which was lasting enough to my liking. Will definitely purchase a bottle!

Deep, dark, rich, oily and a bit floral. Lots of dark chocolate and coffee notes, a bit of smoke,  black roasted sugar. What you get on the nose you will get on the palate. Finish is a nice bitter dark chocolate. A solid American single malt whiskey. I would love to try this at a higher proof. 3.8 or 3.9 would be a fare rating.
Like bourbon and scotch made a baby. Beautiful
